original_title: Sri Lanka to receive Japanese aid for human resource development scholarship
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Japan has agreed to provide Sri Lankan authorities 284 million Japanese yen in aid for a second phase of a human resource development scholarship programme.
The equivalent of 611 million Sri Lankan rupees will be granted to the government for the second batch of the “fourth time frame” for the Japanese aid programme, a statement said.

The cabinet of ministers has approved a proposal by President Ranil Wickremesinghe in his capacity as Minister of Finance to sign letters of exchange with the Japanese government and enter into an agreement with Japan International Cooperation Agency (JAICA) to receive the grant.

“In order to ensure international Japanese cooperation, we are going to sign an agreement with the Japanese government,” cabinet spokesman and Minister of Mass Media Bandula Gunawardena said at a cabinet press briefing on Tuesday July 18.

In February 2023, the Japanese government provided five billion yen to Sri Lanka as aid for the purchase of fuel and diesel for the health sector. This grant was made under Japan’s Economic and Social Development Programme in order to aid the country’s health sector.

“In order to carry out the exchange and signing of the signatures, the president, who also serves as finance minister, must be present,” said Gunawardena. (Colombo/Jul22/2023)
